headline: Close Encounters at the Iowa Democratic Fundraiser
summary: The presidential candidate speed dating here in the state that will start balloting for the nomination in less than eight months showcased the challenges of managing the vast Democratic field.

headline: It May Soon Get Easier to Move Your 401(k) When Switching Jobs
summary: A proposed regulation helps workers bring their retirement accounts with them when they switch jobs.

headline: Warren Buffett Likes ‘Wide Moat’ Stocks. Should You?
summary: Investors love the idea of investing in companies with the best brands, reputations and competitive advantages. That has a downside, research suggests.

headline: The Mistakes That Investors Make With Currency Funds
summary: Because predicting the direction of currencies can be challenging, investors should approach these funds with caution, financial experts say.

headline: Tough Month Cuts U.S.-Stock Funds’ 2019 Gain to 10%
summary: In May, all three things that had been boosting stocks in April—positive market outlooks, Treasury yields and optimism about a U.S.-China trade deal, ended. But the damage may be short-lived.

headline: Which Is the Better Inflation Hedge: Stocks or Gold?
summary: The answer to the stock/gold debate may surprise you, says this columnist.

headline: Here Comes the Sun (and Wind): Renewables Have Their Market Moment
summary: Despite President Trump’s skepticism, wind and solar funds are beating this year’s bull market.

headline: Volatility Fear Drives Investors to Bond ETFs
summary: Some in the industry say investors are looking at ETFs as a risk-management tool because of their flexibility and convenience.

headline: Fund Managers See Opportunities for Investors From Trade Dispute
summary: But others say that it’s a good reminder that investors shouldn’t react to the headlines of the day.

headline: An ETF Counts on Investors Overreacting
summary: Vesper US Large Cap Short-Term Reversal Strategy ETF invests in stocks that have experienced a selloff, but are expected to bounce back quickly.

headline: What Does It Mean When Investors Say, ‘Sell the Profit’?
summary: The term refers to selling stocks in the anticipation that corporate earnings growth is about to slow. Some say it is especially relevant now.

headline: Microsoft to Test New Videogame-Streaming Project
summary: The tech giant will begin publicly testing its new videogame-streaming initiative in October, just ahead of when Google’s competing service is slated to launch.

headline: For Trump, Threats Become Part of Diplomatic Playbook
summary: Using threats of punitive action even against allies to force negotiation has become a staple of President Trump’s diplomatic playbook. As Mr. Trump views it, the threat creates leverage and strengthens the U.S.’s hand.

headline: Deal to Avert Tariffs Leaves Unease Between Trump, GOP
summary: The deal averting tariffs was broadly celebrated by Republicans but left an undercurrent of tension between the president and many in the GOP, especially in the Senate, who dislike tariffs and opposed the Mexico policy.

headline: Mexico Wearies of U.S. Approach
summary: President Trump made Mexico a political piñata from the first day of his presidential campaign. Now, the historically fraught relationship has suffered another major blow.

headline: ‘Big Ugly’ Bill May Emerge in Albany as State Legislature Nears Break
summary: Leaders of the Senate and Assembly will begin serious negotiations this week with Gov. Andrew Cuomo about a host of unresolved issues, from rent control to, potentially, legalizing recreational marijuana.

headline: Renault’s Nissan Ties Are Called a Priority
summary: Strains over a busted merger between Fiat Chrysler and Renault, and lingering hostilities between Renault and its Japanese alliance partner Nissan Motor, spilled out into the open.

headline: Paying for Mexico’s Wall
summary: Trump’s use of tariffs as a bludgeon on migrants has economic costs.

headline: California Greens Have a Cow
summary: Methane emissions expose some anti-carbon contradictions.

headline: Fiduciary Rule Fixer-Upper
summary: A new SEC Best Interest Rule protects investors and cleans up an Obama legal mess.

headline: An Unexpected Farewell for the Four Seasons
summary: The sudden closing of the A-list institution raises questions about the future of high-end dining.

headline: PG&E Can Pull Out of Green-Power Contracts
summary: A court ruling allows the California utility to shed billions in wind and solar deals, threatening scores of electricity suppliers.

headline: PG&E Shuts Power to California Resort Area to Prevent Wildfires
summary: PG&E cut power to customers in a Napa County resort area, the first of what the utility has said will likely be numerous pre-emptive shutdowns this year to help prevent deadly wildfires.

headline: Why Are People Protesting in Hong Kong?
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in Hong Kong on Sunday to oppose amendments to an extradition law that could be passed in coming weeks.

headline: U.S.-Saudi Arms Sales Face More Senate Pushback
summary: Two senators will try to force a vote against U.S. weapons sales to Saudi Arabia, a sign of persistent discontent in some corners of Congress over the Trump administration’s arms-sales policy.

headline: U.S. Commander Weighs an Expanded Mideast Force
summary: The commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East said he may recommend a return to a larger U.S. military presence in the area after concluding that a recent build up there helped curtail Iranian threats.

headline: Trump Militarizes Mexico
summary: The U.S. demands López Obrador use troops to stem northern migration.

headline: Ballplayers Deserve a Stake in Their Teams
summary: Sky-high salaries look great on paper, but only owners get the game’s low-tax spoils.

headline: ‘The American People’ Have Been Spoken To
summary: Politicians lecture us about what we want, need, deserve and are really interested in.

headline: ‘William Walker’s Wars’ Review: A Man in Search of an Empire
summary: Walker wasn’t the only 19th-century adventurer to see the value of seizing Mexican territory, but he was certainly the most audacious.

headline: Biden Gives Trump-Wary Pro-Lifers Nowhere to Hyde
summary: His flip-flop aligns him with his party but makes him more vulnerable than Mrs. Clinton in November.

headline: The Foreign Influence We’re Ignoring
summary: The collusion narrative was bunk, but other countries’ clandestine lobbying is a real problem.

headline: Antitrust, Free Speech and Google
summary: The Justice Department has some authority over the marketplace of ideas.

headline: Who’s Afraid of the Belt and Road?
summary: The ‘debt trap’ results from Beijing’s blunders. It would be a lousy strategy for global influence.

headline: With Labor Market Tight, Some States Loosen Rules for Licensed Jobs
summary: Some states grappling with a low unemployment rate have passed laws that enable licensed workers to cross their borders to find work.

headline: Raytheon, United Technologies in Talks to Merge
summary: United Technologies is near a deal to combine with military contractor Raytheon, the latest move by the sprawling conglomerate to transform into a company focused on aerospace and defense.

headline: Economy Week Ahead: U.S. Inflation, Retail Sales Data
summary: In the week ahead, the U.S. will release new data on inflation and retail sales. Also China’s consumer-price index likely climbed 2.7% in May.

headline: ‘Pets,’ X-Men Franchises Decline at Box Office
summary: A sequel slump hit Hollywood over the weekend, with two new releases opening to franchise lows and a holdover failing to pull in audiences in its second week.

headline: Kraft Heinz Has a Long Road to Redemption
summary: The food giant’s delayed financial filings were finally released, but they make clear that it is too early to celebrate.

headline: Prolonged Flooding Takes Its Toll on a Small Missouri Town
summary: Near-record flooding is expected to linger for days, challenging riverside communities like Kimmswick, Mo., as they fight to keep temporary barriers from collapsing.

headline: Rafael Nadal Always Has Paris
summary: Rafael Nadal beat Dominic Thiem to win his 12th French Open title. It is the Spaniard’s 18th Grand Slam win.

headline: Debating the Uses of Donald Trump’s Tariffs
summary: Tariffs will cause us to buy less from Mexicans, who will have fewer dollars to buy goods from us, generating unemployment here and in Mexico.

headline: Some Unions See Single-Payer’s Advantages
summary: The skyrocketing cost of care is why I and the nurses of the New York State Nurses Association support the New York Health Act—single-payer legislation that will guarantee health care to everyone.

headline: Warriors Beat Expectations, Ended Up at the Cow Palace
summary: The Warriors won their 1975 Championship at the Cow Palace.

headline: Disney’s Boycott of Georgia Should Apply In Every Way
summary: There is no reason to take money from, or make a profit in, a state that is not worthy of being a work site.

headline: To Stop Robocalls, Parties Need to Understand Who Is a Robocaller
summary: There is little debate that robocalls meant to deceive consumers are bad, and that calls from schools or doctors’ offices are typically benign. It is the large middle ground of calls to consumers by legitimate businesses where the FCC hasn’t set clear rules.

headline: Bad News on Trade Is Good News for Banks
summary: Banks’ revenues from financing cross-border commerce are in the best shape in years, despite President Trump’s threats of Mexican tariffs, stalled progress on a U.S.-China accord and the U.K.’s impending Brexit.

headline: Police Detain 100 as Kazakhstan Votes in First Election Since Fall of Soviet Union
summary: Voters in Kazakhstan went to the polls Sunday to vote for a new president in an election critics have called undemocratic and said underscores growing authoritarianism in the former Soviet country.

headline: G-20 Financial Leaders Criticize Trade Tensions for Impact on Growth
summary: The Group of 20 major economies decried worsening trade tensions and their impact on global growth, with the U.S. and China locked in a protracted trade battle since negotiations fell apart a month ago.

headline: Hong Kong Residents Stage Huge Protest Against Extradition
summary: Thousands of people protested in Hong Kong on Sunday against a proposed law that would allow individuals to be extradited to mainland China to stand trial.

headline: New Book Sheds Friendly Light on Trump as Businessman
summary: George Sorial, former Trump Organization chief compliance counsel, wrote about working for Donald Trump in “The Real Deal,” offering a glowing portrait of the president’s business instincts and management tactics.

headline: At Christie’s Auctions, Visitors Get Up Close and Personal
summary: Auction houses allow some visitors to do what is unthinkable at a museum: Take a painting off the wall.

headline: You Can Mute Emails, Texts, Tweets and More—And You Should
summary: Muting someone online is like putting in invisible earplugs: The talkers can keep talking, but you don’t have to listen. And they’ll never know the difference

headline: World Trade Center’s Oculus Skylight Likely Won’t Be Fixed Before 9/11 Anniversary
summary: The retractable skylight at the $3.9 billion World Trade Center Oculus in Manhattan is unlikely to open this year on the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Bets on Falling Interest Rates Unleash Gold Rally
summary: Gold is on its longest winning streak in almost a year and a half, the latest signal that investors are preparing for the Fed to lower interest rates amid signs of a slowdown in economic growth.

headline: Hold the Applause for a Rate Cut
summary: When the Federal Reserve cuts rates, it is usually because something bad is happening. Investors, in their joy over the prospect of Fed easing, may have lost sight of that.

headline: Fed Should Ignore Trump and Study Cuts for Right Reasons
summary: At a time when the need for easier money is debatable, it would be natural for monetary policy makers to snub President Trump’s calls for interest-rate cuts to prove their impartiality. But it would be a mistake.

headline: Abraaj Collapse Highlights U.A.E.’s Foreign Worker Pension Plight
summary: Nearly a year after Dubai-based private-equity firm Abraaj Group filed for provisional liquidation, many of its former foreign workers—from deal makers to secretaries and butlers—are still waiting to get paid.

headline: Food Truck Warrior Ponders Next Step in Battle With Chicago
summary: Food-truck owner Laura Pekarik has waged a so-far unsuccessful battle against Chicago’s tough rules restricting where the trucks can park. She and her lawyer are weighing whether to appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court after losing a challenge in Illinois’s top court.

headline: Small Businesses Aren’t Rushing Into AI
summary: Artificial intelligence over the past decade has shifted from research theories to actual practices in corporate offices. But it isn’t within the reach of many smaller companies, yet.

headline: Russia Detains Journalist on Drug Charges, Rattling Media Community
summary: The detention of a prominent Russian journalist known for investigating corruption has rattled the media community in the country and highlights the pressure faced by news outlets fighting to preserve their independence.

headline: Some Investors Had Hunch Yields Were About to Fall
summary: Although almost no one saw the nosedive in government bond yields coming, a few were positioned well enough to profit. Some think there is room for yields to fall further.

headline: Top U.S., Chinese Officials Break the Ice on Trade
summary: China and the U.S. held their first high-level meeting on trade since negotiations fell apart a month ago, with U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin saying he had a candid exchange with China’s central bank governor.

headline: Courting Black Voters in South Carolina, Harris Defends Her Record
summary: Sen. Kamala Harris vigorously defended her record as a prosecutor, accusing critics of inaccurately trying to define her as she courted a state, and a constituency, that could be crucial to her hopes of winning the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Bonds for College Savings: The Pros and Cons
summary: Savings bonds don’t have all of the tax advantages that 529 plans offer.

headline: Star Fund Manager Bill Miller Is Still Betting Big
summary: He once beat the market 15 years in a row—a streak that still holds the record. Here’s what he thinks about the market today.

headline: Where Emerging-Markets Investments Are Going
summary: China took the most during a recent 16-month period, as ETFs focused on Chinese companies snapped up cheap stocks.

headline: Factories Throttle Back, Pressuring U.S. Economy
summary: Factories have shifted into low gear after a year of record output and big job gains, putting additional pressure on a U.S. economy that already is expected to grow more slowly this year.

headline: Tariff Dispute Complicates U.S. Ties With Mexico
summary: President Trump’s threat to impose tariffs on Mexico was averted by an immigration deal late Friday, but scrambles anew the already-delicate relationship between two neighbors struggling to resolve the trade and border issues that are top priorities for the White House.

headline: Democratic Candidates Take Aim at Biden in Iowa
summary: Several 2020 candidates sought to contrast themselves with Joe Biden at the Iowa Hall of Fame celebration, one of the party’s annual fundraisers. The heightened combativeness served as a preview to the first primary debates late this month.

headline: The Eternal City Tries to Defeat Its Roamin’ Centurions
summary: Fake ancient soldiers, accused of hassling tourists, now fight rear-guard action against local authorities.

headline: The South’s Economy Is Falling Behind: ‘All of a Sudden the Money Stops Flowing’
summary: Policies that once drove the region’s growth—relatively low taxes and low wages that attracted factories and blue-collar jobs—have proven inadequate in an economy where the forces of globalization favor cities with concentrations of capital and educated workers.

headline: Massive Crowds Take to Streets in ‘Last Fight’ for Hong Kong
summary: Huge crowds of demonstrators took to the streets Sunday to protest a proposed law that would allow Beijing to take people from Hong Kong to stand trial in mainland China.

headline: Mexico Avoids Tariffs for Now, but the Threat Lingers
summary: The deal the U.S. and Mexico struck to prevent the U.S. from imposing tariffs largely reaffirms the countries’ commitments to existing measures on immigration but will allow Washington to keep up pressure on Mexico.

headline: Inside the Luxury Condo That New York Says Was an Illegal Airbnb Operation
summary: At the Atelier, a condominium building in New York City, the board president and a small travel agency built a lucrative lodging business, according to people with knowledge of the rental arrangements.

headline: Pakistan Grapples With Unprecedented HIV Infections in Children
summary: When a doctor sounded alarm bells about children mysteriously testing positive for HIV, health officials decided to offer screening to his entire town. What they found, the World Health Organization said, was unprecedented.
